title: How to Clean a Can Opener

steps.title: Place the can opener into a jar pour white vinegar in.
steps.content: Place the can opener into a jar pour white vinegar in. A glass jar, coffee can, or any similar container will work. Take the can opener and insert it top-first into the jar. Then, pour white vinegar into the jar so it covers all of the can opener's moving parts. [1] X Research source You can use a bowl instead of a jar as long as all of the can opener’s moving parts fit inside it. Vinegar's acidity helps to break down built up rust and gunk. White vinegar is sometimes called distilled vinegar.

steps.title: Let the can opener soak for 20-60 minutes.
steps.content: Let the can opener soak for 20-60 minutes. The vinegar needs some time to loosen the gunk and rust. Let it sit for at least 20 minutes, and up to an hour. Some of the gunk may start flaking off and floating in the vinegar, indicating that it’s working. [2] X Research source If your can opener is so dirty or rusty that the moving parts don’t work well, then you’ll have to soak it longer. Try leaving it overnight so the vinegar can really work at the gunk. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub the can opener’s moving parts with a toothbrush and vinegar.
steps.content: Scrub the can opener’s moving parts with a toothbrush and vinegar. After the can opener has soaked in the vinegar, take the jar to the sink and remove it. Dip a toothbrush into the vinegar, then scrub the can opener. Focus on the gears and moving parts. Scrub in a circular motion to work off the gunk and rust. [4] X Research source Depending on the can opener type, you may have to open it up to reach the gears. If rust is built up outside the moving parts, scrub here as well.

steps.title: Add dish soap to the toothbrush and scrub again.
steps.content: Add dish soap to the toothbrush and scrub again. Hold the can opener and brush under the faucet to rinse it, the squeeze a dab of dish soap onto the toothbrush. Scrub the can opener again with the soap. Focus on the gears and moving parts like you did before to work off any remaining rust. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse the can opener with clean water.
steps.content: Rinse the can opener with clean water. Hold the can opener under the faucet and rinse it well. Make sure no suds are left behind. [6] X Research source Soap scum can attract dirt and cause rusting, so make sure to rinse the can opener well.

steps.title: Dry the can opener thoroughly.
steps.content: Dry the can opener thoroughly. Leftover water will cause further rusting, so make sure your hard work isn’t wasted. Take a dry cloth and wipe all the moisture off the can opener. Dry the entire device, especially the moving parts. Then leave the can opener out in the sun so the rest of the water evaporates before you put it away. [7] X Research source If the cloth can’t reach into the gears, then blow hard into them to push off any hidden moisture.

steps.title: Unplug the can opener's power cord.
steps.content: Unplug the can opener's power cord. Never try to clean the can opener without unplugging it first. This can result in a serious injury if your finger gets stuck. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the blade bracket if it comes off.
steps.content: Remove the blade bracket if it comes off. On some electric can opener models, the black bracket is removable for cleaning. If yours works this way, look for a switch or knob to detach the bracket. Then lift it out of position. [9] X Research source Different models may have different methods for detaching the bracket. Check the instruction manual for your can opener for the correct process. If your can opener bracket is not detachable, you can still clean the gears with a toothbrush and white vinegar.

steps.title: Soak the blade bracket in a bowl of white vinegar for 30-60 minutes.
steps.content: Soak the blade bracket in a bowl of white vinegar for 30-60 minutes. Place the bracket in a bowl and fill it with white vinegar. Make sure the vinegar covers the whole bracket. Then leave it undisturbed for 30-60 minutes so the vinegar loosens all the rust and grime. [10] X Research source If your can opener was so rusted or dirty that the gears wouldn't move, then leave it soaking longer. Wait overnight so the grime loosens better. If your blade bracket isn't removable, then skip to the next step.

steps.title: Scrub the gears with a toothbrush and vinegar.
steps.content: Scrub the gears with a toothbrush and vinegar. After letting the bracket soak for 30-60 minutes, remove it and dip a toothbrush into the vinegar. Then scrub all the moving parts in the blade bracket. Work in a circular motion to push off all the rust and grime. You may have to re-wet the brush with more vinegar to work off more difficult stains. [11] X Research source If the blade bracket isn't removable and hasn't been soaking in vinegar, then you'll have to scrub more. Really soak the toothbrush in vinegar and scrub hard from multiple different directions to work the grime off.

steps.title: Scrub the bracket again with dish soap and water.
steps.content: Scrub the bracket again with dish soap and water. Hold the bracket and brush under the faucet to rinse them, then squeeze a dab of dish soap onto the toothbrush. Scrub the bracket again with the soap. Focus on the gears and moving parts like you did before to work off any remaining rust. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse the bracket with clean water and dry it completely.
steps.content: Rinse the bracket with clean water and dry it completely. Hold the bracket under the faucet and rinse it well. Make sure no suds are left behind! Take a dry cloth and wipe all the moisture off the bracket, especially the moving parts. If possible, leave the bracket out in the sun so the rest of the water evaporates. [13] X Research source [14] X Research source Soap scum can attract dirt and cause rust, so be sure to rinse the bracket well. Dry the bracket thoroughly. If the cloth can’t reach into the gears, then blow on them to push off any hidden moisture.

steps.title: Place the bracket back onto the can opener.
steps.content: Place the bracket back onto the can opener. Once the bracket is completely dry, follow the steps in the instruction manual for connecting it back onto the can opener. Plug the cord back in and test the can opener to make sure all the moving parts work properly. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Get a stainless steel can opener to resist rust.
steps.content: Get a stainless steel can opener to resist rust. Stainless steel resists rusting and gunk buildup much better than other metals. Look for a stainless steel type to cut down on the amount of cleaning you’ll have to do. A stainless steel can opener may be a bit more expensive than other models, but it’s the best can opener to resist rusting.

steps.title: Rinse and dry the can opener after every use.
steps.content: Rinse and dry the can opener after every use. Moisture and leftover food particles encourage rusting and mold growth. Rinse your can opener under the faucet after every use to get rid of trapped food and gunk. Then, dry it thoroughly with a cloth to prevent rusting. [16] X Research source Leave the can opener out on the countertop to dry, even after you’ve wiped it with a cloth. Moisture doesn’t evaporate as well inside drawers.

steps.title: Use a hair dryer to dry hard-to-reach areas.
steps.content: Use a hair dryer to dry hard-to-reach areas. If your can opener rusts often, then you may not be drying it enough. After cleaning the can opener, try holding it up to a hair dryer for a few minutes to blast hidden moisture out of the gears and moving parts. [17] X Research source Hold the can opener with a rag or oven mitt while you do this. The metal could get very hot from the hair dryer.
